reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Humanitarian assistance to meet the basic needs of Palestine refugees from hard to reach areas

description.narrative: The basic needs of Palestine refugees in Syria continue to deepen, and due to underfunding UNRWA was only able to provide three rounds of cash assistance throughout 2015, covering just six months of needs. This included refugees in hard to reach locations. The Agency undertook a verification exercise in tandem with the second round of cash assistance, and found that out of the total population which remains in Syria, more than 95 percent are in need of assistance. UNRWA proposes to distribute cash to approximately 29,205 refugees from hard to reach areas, which currently include Qudsayya, Khan Eshieh and Ramadan Camp in the greater Damascus area, as well as Mzeirib, Jillien and other villages around Dera’a. Each refugee will receive USD 64 to support food (USD 40), shelter and NFI (USD 24) needs for two months. Palestine refugees rely heavily on UNRWA for basic services and humanitarian assistance. Cash assistance continues to be the most appropriate form of assistance to refugees as it enables each family to cope with their most pressing needs, as they receive the assistance. In the above hard to reach areas, it remains relevant while food is available on open markets and where crossing front lines with cash presents fewer issues than carrying in-kind items. UNRWA distributes cash through a total of 35 distribution points, including bank branches, money transfer outlets and one UNRWA facility. Refugees are able to cross front-lines to collect assistance from these nearby locations. Verification, monitoring and post-distribution mechanisms are well-established and the latest evaluation of the programme found that cash is the preferred distribution method for more than 95% of the population.
